top_comment.text:
Warren 2016 is a terrible idea, and I say that as someone who would like to 
see her elected President at some point in the future. She is a first term 
senator with zero experience in elected office at any level of government 
prior to her 2012 campaign. Yes, Obama was a first term senator as well, 
but he spent almost eight years in the Illinois State Senate before being 
elected to federal office so it's not a fair comparison. If we put her up 
as nominee in 2016, assuming Clinton doesn't run and proceed to utterly 
smash her in the primaries, Warren will lose and lose badly as the 
Republicans paint her as an inexperienced New England radical leftist who 
will drive the country into the ground. In 2020 or 2024 (depending on if we 
win in 2016) she will have spent far more time in elected office, built up 
a much greater national reputation, and be a far more potent threat to the 
Republicans and corporatist Democrats than she would be now. At this point 
in time, I think she's doing way more good as a first term senator who is 
quickly gaining a reputation as a defender of the lower and middle classes 
than she'd be doing as either a sacrificial lamb leftist anti-Clinton 
option or a Presidential nominee. If we need a more progressive 
anti-Clinton option in the primary, let someone like Martin O'Malley (who 
will have more than 15 years experience in elected office by the time the 
primaries roll around) take up that role. Then if he somehow managed to 
pull off a victory against the Clinton juggernaut, we'd actually have a 
candidate that's capable of winning on the national level in 2016, and if 
he lost the primary, we wouldn't be damaging the reputation of a senator 
that I could easily see running an extremely credible campaign for the 
Presidency given another couple cycles. I get why people are excited about 
the possibility of Warren running, but I just don't see this being her year 
when you look at things realistically.﻿

comments.text:
One, Romneycare was created by Mitt Romney, who was most definitely not a 
conservative. At best, he was a moderate. Secondly, did the Heritage 
foundation at one point have an alternate to the Clinton idea of universal 
healthcare, yes, and it was an individual mandate. But was it anything like 
the individual mandate of today that is in Obamacare, absolutely not. 
Firstly, the point of the mandate was to protect others, not themselves. If 
someone gets in a bad wreck, and didn't have insurance, than the state 
would pay for that. The Mandate would get rid of that, because everyone 
would have health insurance. Secondly, they wanted people to get healthcare 
by the "carrot" and not the "stick". They would provide rewards for those 
who got them. Not a punishment. Finally, the mandate said that if you 
didn't buy health insurance, than you would lose some tax breaks. It was 
not a legal requirement to buy health insurance. 
So about the only connection you can draw between the two is that more 
people would be on insurance. It is how it happens. So in otherwords, there 
is no way that you can say Obamacare came out of a Heritage Foundation idea.

comments.text:
What requirements Bill? Share with us in your wealth of knowledge what 
Senator Warren has told the financial institutions that they must do? 

By the end of "too big to fail," the government chose to bail out only the 
big banks. Not the little ones that suffered the must and therefore went 
bankrupt. The loss of little banks and even some of the bigger financial 
institutions like Lehmann Brothers meant that the Big Four remaining 
(Goldmann, Citigroup, and such) could just gobble up the left overs and 
make themselves bigger. Our politicians did not stop them.  You ask me why? 
Well let tell you Bill.  It's because big financial institutions invest 
heavily into campaign funds and they want some favors just every once in a 
while. 

Now what does Senator Warren have to do with this? Well Senator Warren at 
the time wasn't even Senator Warren.  She was not even in politics.  She 
was professor of law, a mother, a grandmother, and writer, who had 
predicted the financial collapse a decade prior to 2008.  But when the 
world collapsed, the government reached out to her to help oversee the 
congressional TARP oversight. What powers did this give her? The TARP 
oversight gave money and demanded a certain repayment plans. But then TARP 
didn't effect small banks?! That's right Bill. TARP didn't effect small 
banks because they didn't give them money in the first place to have rules 
on them.  

But did Senator Warren do anything else? Well yes Bill. She championed the 
Consumer Financial Protection Bureau which look for fraud and repayment to 
the consumers.  What has the CFPB done? Well in its 3 years, it has fined 
$400 million dollars in fraud and returned it to the consumers.  People 
like you and I bill can send an email to CFPB and say "well I think my 
credit card company is screwing me over again." The CFPB sees enough people 
all pointing to the same company and they investigate. Isn't that exciting? 
Well it sure is because now I don't need to fight the big bank by myself 
anymore.  
I like it when we talk Bill. I feel like we both learn a lot. Well maybe 
mostly you, but I still like our talks.
comments.author: ctkle

comments.text:
+ctkle Funny thing is that Warren has actually allowed big banks to become 
bigger.  Basically only the large banks can pony up the money to meet the 
requirements that she promoted.  This is almost always the case.  For 
example, there is a new rule that requires restaurants of a certain size to 
add nutritional information about their food.  Only the bigger restaurants 
can afford to do the testing that is required to meet these requirements 
thus pushing out competition.  The same thing is happening in toy 
manufacturing, banking, etc.  But Grubers like you just think she is 
helping the little people.
